name: Wild Side Canyon
description:
Introduction

Miners first discovered this canyon mine prospecting and left remains along the way. A short but fun narrow canyon that drops rapidly to the Colorado River.

Approach

Approach is from Gold Strike Canyon. There is a break along the way that takes you to a saddle where you get great views of the river and the bridge. You will have to pick your way down a steep slope by heading right.

Descent

Once in the canyon you will head into some narrow corridors and find 6 raps up to 180 ft. A couple raps are overhung, and all of the raps have webbing. Do not place bolts in the canyon. You will notice miners placed eye bolts in the canyon when they prospected through the region in the past. Eventually you will come to a beautiful hot spring aquafer discharge where hanging gardens with hot spring water rain down. One cavern you can enter and it will rain hot spring water just like a shower. walk a short distance to the river, inflate your packraft and head for your exit.

Exit

We exited out of the Secret canyon exit as it was less gain and distance but against the rivers current.

Red tape

Do not place bolts in this canyon or any canyon. Bring webbing and Rapides to change our anchorage. You must have a USCG approved raft and PFD. have a shuttle car set up at the secret canyon trailhead if you are using that exit.

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

Originally and still known as Emery Canyon by the first known complete descent in 2013.
